Graphical abstract The selective hydrodeoxygenation of furfural (FFR) to 2-methylfuran (2-MF) is crucial for the high-value utilization of biomass resources. In this study, a series of NinSn1/MoOx (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) catalysts with varying metal ratios were synthesized via a glycine-assisted auto-ignition method and evaluated for FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF. The results reveal that an optimal Sn loading enhances the Ni-Sn interaction, promoting the formation of Ni-Sn alloys and improving the dispersion of metal nanoparticles. More importantly, the appropriate Sn addition facilitates the generation of SnO species, which serve as Lewis acid sites and accelerate the hydrodeoxygenation of the intermediate furfuryl alcohol (FA) to 2-MF. In-situ DRIFTS analysis demonstrates that Sn incorporation strengthens the adsorption of the CO group in FFR and the COH group in FA, thereby enhancing 2-MF formation. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations further indicate that the Ni4Sn1 (111) crystal surface exhibits the lowest d-band center and the strongest electronic effect. Consequently, this surface shows the highest adsorption energies for H2, FFR, and FA, the lowest adsorption energies for H* and 2-MF, and the smallest energy barrier for the conversion of FA to 2-MF. As a result, the Ni4Sn1/MoOx catalyst achieves exceptional performance, delivering a 99.8 % yield of 2-MF at 170 °C. This work provides a novel strategy for designing efficient non-noble metal catalysts for the selective conversion of biomass-derived furfural to 2-MF. Keywords Furfural 2-MF Hydrodeoxygenation Ni-Sn alloys Lewis acid sites Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The overuse of fossil fuels has exacerbated energy shortages and environmental pollution, driving recent research efforts toward the development of biofuels and chemicals derived from renewable biomass resources [1]. Lignocellulosic biomass, with its rapid growth cycle, abundant reserves, and low cost, presents a promising alternative to conventional fossil fuels [2]. However, its high oxygen content results in biofuels with low energy density, rendering them unsuitable for direct use [3,4]. Therefore, converting lignocellulosic biomass-derived platform compounds into high-value chemicals and biofuels is crucial. Among the various upgrading strategies, hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) plays a pivotal role in reducing oxygen content and enhancing fuel quality [5]. As one of the most important platform compounds derived from lignocellulosic biomass, furfural (FFR) is produced through the hydrolysis and dehydration of cellulose and hemicellulose [6,7]. Featuring both an aldehyde group and a furan ring, FFR serves as a versatile precursor for various value-added chemicals and biofuels [2,7], including furfuryl alcohol (FA) [7], tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) [8], 2-methylfuran (2-MF) [2,6,9], 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) [10], cyclopentanone (CPO) [11], and 1,5-pentanediol [12]. Of these derivatives, 2-MF produced via selective hydrodeoxygenation of furfural is particularly valuable as a chemical intermediate, finding extensive applications in flavor, pharmaceutical, and pesticide industries [13]. Moreover, 2-MF serves as an excellent gasoline additive due to its high octane number, rapid combustion rate, and outstanding anti-knock properties [14,15]. Its inclusion in vehicle fuel standards further underscores its industrial importance [16]. The conversion of abundant and low-cost FFR into 2-MF thus represents a crucial strategy for addressing energy and environmental challenges while promoting sustainable development. The HDO of FFR yields various products through multiple reaction pathways. The primary challenge in selectively producing 2-methylfuran (2-MF) lies in removing the carbonyl oxygen while preserving the furan ring structure [2]. This selectivity requirement underscores the critical importance of catalyst design for 2-MF synthesis. Adkins et al. [17] first demonstrated 2-MF production via FFR hydrodeoxygenation using Cu-Cr catalysts. While these catalysts showed moderate activity and selectivity, the environmental toxicity of chromium rendered them unsuitable for sustainable applications. In recent years, extensive research has been conducted on various catalysts for the HDO of FFR to 2-MF. Sulfide catalysts, such as Co-MoS2–x [18], were widely used in HDO reactions. However, these catalysts face limitations due to potential sulfur contamination in products and susceptibility to water-induced deactivation. Noble metal catalysts, including Pt [19,20], Pd [21,22], and Ru [23,24], have demonstrated high activity and selectivity for 2-MF production. For instance, Chang et al. achieved an 83.9 % combined yield of 2-MF and 2-MTHF by optimizing Pd loading in Cu-Pd catalysts [22]. Similarly, Panagiotopoulou et al. identified Ru and RuOx as active phases in Ru/C catalysts, obtaining a 61 % 2-MF yield at 180°C after 5 h [23]. Nevertheless, the excessive hydrogenation activity of noble metals often leads to undesirable side reactions, reducing 2-MF selectivity. Their high cost further limits practical applications. Consequently, attention has shifted to non-noble metal catalysts (e.g., Ni [25–27], Co [6,18,28], Cu [25,29–31]). Srivastava et al. demonstrated that oxygen vacancy concentration critically governs 2-MF selectivity, achieving a 98.1 % yield of 2-MF through controlled oxygen vacancy regulation in NiAl2O4 catalysts [27]. Subsequently, they attained a 97.0 % yield of 2-MF using CuFe2O4 inverse spinel catalysts [29]. Among these, Ni-based catalysts are particularly promising due to their cost-effectiveness and excellent hydrogenation capability. However, their strong interaction with the furan ring often results in excessive hydrogenation, compromising product selectivity. Ni-based catalysts tend to promote tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) formation rather than the desired deoxygenation product 2-MF during furfural hydrogenation [32]. To address this limitation, oxyphilic metals such as Ga [33], Sn [34], and Fe [26] have been incorporated into Ni-based catalysts to form alloys or intermetallic compounds. These additives effectively suppress furan ring hydrogenation by modifying the geometric and electronic properties of Ni. Specifically, they inhibit C–C bond adsorption and hydrogenolysis while enhancing the adsorption and activation of CO/CO groups [6,33,34]. Among these modifiers, Sn has emerged as particularly promising due to its cost-effectiveness and commercial availability. Sn demonstrates exceptional performance in liquid-phase aldehyde hydrogenation, enabling selective CO bond hydrogenation while maintaining furan ring stability [35]. In this study, Ni-Sn bimetallic catalysts were synthesized via a glycine-assisted auto-ignition method for the selective hydrodeoxygenation of FFR to 2-MF. The results demonstrate that optimal Sn loading facilitates both the formation of Ni-Sn alloys and the generation of SnO species, which collectively enhance the HDO efficiency toward 2-MF production. More importantly, in-situ DRIFTS and DFT calculations provided mechanistic insights into: the influence of Ni/Sn ratios on catalytic performance, and the reaction pathway for FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF. 2 Experimental Detailed descriptions of the chemicals, characterization methods, catalytic performance evaluation procedures, and DFT calculation methodologies are provided in the Supporting Information. 2.1 Synthesis of Ni/MoOx The Ni/MoOx catalyst was synthesized via a glycine-assisted auto-ignition method. Briefly, a certain amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and glycine were dissolved in deionized water, named solution A. Moreover, a certain amount of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O was dissolved in heated deionized water and labeled as solution B. Afterward, solution A was added dropwise to Solution B under continuous stirring. The resulting mixture was aged at 60°C for 12 h. The aged solution was concentrated by heating to 90 °C in an oil bath, followed by drying at 120°C for 24 h. The dried solid was ground and subjected to a two-stage calcination in a muffle furnace: initial calcination at 300°C for 30 min, and then the temperature was ramped to 700 °C at 1 °C/min and maintained for 6 h to obtain the catalyst precursor. Finally, the calcined precursor was reduced under flowing H2 at 450 ℃ for 3 h to obtain the Ni/MoOx catalyst. 2.2 Synthesis of NinSn1/MoOx (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) The bimetallic NinSn1/MoOx catalysts were prepared following the same glycine-assisted auto-ignition method as the monometallic Ni/MoOx catalyst, with the following modification: SnCl2·2H2O was incorporated into solution A during precursor preparation. The resulting catalysts were reduced under identical conditions and designated as NinSn1/MoOx, where n represents the Ni/Sn molar ratio (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the samples Fig. 1 (a) illustrates the synthesis procedure for the bimetallic NinSn1/MoOx catalysts. Nitrogen physisorption analysis (Fig. S1) reveals that all catalysts exhibit type IV isotherms, characteristic of mesoporous materials. Moreover, the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the catalysts are summarized in Table S1. As shown in Table S1, the specific surface area of the catalysts decreases significantly from 66.6 m2·g−1 to 19.7 m2·g−1 as the Sn content increases. The reason may be that the metal particles and SnOx species partially obstruct the pores and surface of the support. It implies that the excessive addition of Sn causes changes in the catalyst structure, hence affecting the catalytic performance [36,37]. The contents of Ni and Sn in the catalysts were analyzed by ICP-OES, and the results are listed in Table S1. Theoretically, the calculated value of the total metal loading in the catalyst was about 20 wt%. As shown in Table S1, the actual Ni content in the monometallic catalyst closely matches the theoretically calculated values. Furthermore, the measured Ni/Sn mass ratios in all bimetallic catalysts show good agreement with the designed stoichiometries, confirming the successful synthesis of catalysts with controlled composition. The XRD patterns of the samples calcined at 700 ℃ are shown in Fig. 1(b). The diffraction peaks located at 25.6°, 38.9°, and 67.6° are attributed to the MoO3. Moreover, the detection of nickel molybdate (NiMoO4) diffraction peaks in all catalysts confirms the presence of Ni species primarily as NiMoO4 phases [37–39]. The diffraction peak intensities of NiMoO4 in the bimetallic catalysts progressively increase with rising Ni content, demonstrating a clear composition-dependent phase evolution. Most significantly, the diffraction peaks observed at 26.7°, 34.0°, 51.9°, and 54.9° correspond to the (110), (101), (211), and (220) crystal planes of SnO2, respectively, confirming successful Sn incorporation into the catalyst [40,41]. Fig. 1(c) presents the XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts (450 °C). The diffraction peaks observed at 37.2° in all catalysts correspond to NiO, while the peak at 26.1° originates from the support [42,43]. Furthermore, the absence of SnO2 diffraction peaks in the bimetallic catalysts indicates the reduction of SnO2 species, which aligns with the XPS results presented in Fig. 2 (d). For the monometallic Ni/MoOx, two characteristic diffraction peaks appear at 44.3° and 51.4°, which correspond to the (111) and (200) crystal planes of metallic Ni (JCPDS No. 04-0850), respectively, confirming the successful reduction of nickel species to Ni0 under the given conditions [42,44–46]. As evident from the enlarged view in Fig. 1(c), the diffraction peak at 44.3° undergoes a significant shift following Sn introduction. This observation confirms Ni-Sn alloy formation, resulting from Sn incorporation into the Ni crystal lattice during reduction [46–49]. Notably, the bimetallic catalysts exhibit weaker Ni-Sn alloy diffraction peak intensities compared to the monometallic counterpart. This attenuation demonstrates that Sn incorporation enhances Ni-Sn synergistic interactions and thus promotes higher dispersion of alloy nanoparticles. The Ni-Sn alloy diffraction peak intensities show a non-monotonic variation with increasing Sn content, initially decreasing before rising again. Among them, the Ni4Sn1/MoOx catalyst exhibits the minimum peak intensity, suggesting optimal dispersion of Ni-Sn alloy nanoparticles at this stoichiometric ratio. Fig. S2 displays the SEM images of Ni/MoOx and NinSn1/MoOx (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5). The catalysts with different Ni/Sn ratios exhibit distinct morphological characteristics. Notably, excessive Sn loading results in larger, irregularly shaped agglomerates, whereas an optimal Sn content yields a more homogeneous particle distribution. Figs. 1(e-h) and S3 display the TEM and HRTEM images of Ni/MoOx and NinSn1/MoOx (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5). As shown in Fig. 1(e), the monometallic Ni/MoOx catalyst exhibits significant nanoparticle sintering, with an average particle size of 14.1 nm. Moreover, as evidenced by Table S1, the bimetallic catalysts demonstrate superior nanoparticle dispersion compared to their monometallic counterpart, with a significant reduction in metal nanoparticle size following Sn incorporation. This improvement confirms that Ni-Sn synergistic interactions effectively suppress nanoparticle sintering while enhancing dispersion, thereby boosting catalytic performance. (Fig. 1(d)) [46,50]. Interestingly, the nanoparticle size follows a non-monotonic trend with Sn loading, initially increasing then decreasing. This behavior suggests an optimal Sn concentration exists for maximal sintering inhibition of metal nanoparticles. In particular, the Ni4Sn1/MoOx catalyst shows the smallest average particle size of 5.7 nm (Fig. 1(g)), highlighting that the content of Sn can significantly influence on catalyst nanostructure. The reducibility of the samples is examined through H2-TPR and the results are presented in Fig. 2(a). The monometallic Ni/MoOx catalyst exhibits two well-defined reduction peaks in the temperature ranges of 480–580 °C and 650–735 °C, which correspond to the reduction of weakly bound NiO particles and the reduction of support-diffused NiO species, respectively [38,52,53]. Moreover, the bimetallic NinSn1/MoOx catalysts exhibit an additional reduction peak at 590–650 ℃, corresponding to the sequential reduction of SnO2 species to SnO or Sn0 [54]. Furthermore, in the bimetallic NinSn1/MoOx catalysts, the high-temperature reduction peak (650–735 ℃) systematically shifts to higher temperatures with increasing Sn content. This positive correlation suggests that excessive Sn doping hinders the reducibility of metal species in the catalysts [48,50,53]. The results demonstrate that optimal Sn doping facilitates both catalyst reducibility and Ni-Sn alloy formation. Significantly, Ni4Sn1/MoOx exhibits the lowest reduction temperature and highest hydrogen consumption, suggesting the strongest Ni-Sn synergistic interaction and maximum formation of hydrogenation-active sites, which is in agreement with the results of XPS in Table 1 . Fig. 2(b) shows the H2-TPD profiles of the catalysts. The monometallic Ni/MoOx catalyst exhibits a broad hydrogen desorption peak between 200 and 580 ℃, corresponding to the desorption of H adsorbed on the metallic Ni sites [50]. In addition, the Ni/MoOx catalyst exhibits the lowest H2 desorption peak intensity, indicating its comparatively weak hydrogen adsorption and activation capability [7]. Furthermore, the H2-TPD profiles reveal two distinct desorption peaks for the bimetallic catalysts, low-temperature desorption peaks at ∼ 110 ℃ (Ni1Sn1/MoOx) and ∼160 °C (NinSn1/MoOx, n = 2, 3, 4, 5), corresponding to physically adsorbed H2. Noticeably, the bimetallic catalysts exhibit stronger H2 desorption peak intensities compared to the monometallic Ni/MoOx catalyst, confirming that the addition of Sn significantly enhances hydrogen activation capability [7]. These results further confirm that Ni-Sn synergistic interactions promote the formation of highly dispersed Ni-Sn alloy nanoparticles and increase exposure of catalytically active sites. More importantly, Ni4Sn1/MoOx exhibits the strongest H2 peak intensity, implying that it possesses both optimal nanoparticle dispersion and maximal exposure of active sites. Unfortunately, the H2 desorption peak intensities decrease progressively with increasing Sn content beyond the optimal ratio, demonstrating that excessive Sn doping inhibits catalyst reducibility and compromises hydrogen adsorption capacity, which agrees well with the results of H2-TPR in Fig. 2(a). These results demonstrate that optimal Sn doping enhances both hydrogen adsorption capacity and activation capability, thereby significantly improving the hydrogenation activity of the catalysts. Fig. S4 displays the survey XPS spectra of catalysts with varying Ni/Sn ratios. The spectra confirm the presence of Ni, Sn, Mo, O, and C elements, verifying successful Sn incorporation into the catalyst structure. The XPS spectra of Ni 2p and Sn 3d for Ni/MoOx and NinSn1/MoOx after reduction at 450℃ are depicted in Fig. 2(c, d). The Ni 2p3/2 XPS spectra in Fig. 2(c) exhibit characteristic peaks at 853.0 eV, 856.2 eV, and 861.5 eV, which are assigned to Ni0, Ni2+, and satellite peaks, respectively [38,48,55]. Significantly, the Ni0 2p3/2 peak shifts from 853.0 eV to 852.8 eV upon Sn incorporation, indicating electron transfer from Sn to Ni. This negative binding energy shift demonstrates that the strong Ni-Sn electronic interaction promotes the formation of Ni-Sn alloy and increases electron density at Ni sites [46,48,49]. In addition, Tables 1 and 2 reveal a non-monotonic trend in Ni0 and Sn0 content with increasing Sn loading, initially rising before declining at higher concentrations. This behavior suggests that excessive Sn deposition forms a surface Sn-rich layer, thereby inhibiting Ni species reduction [47]. Notably, Ni4Sn1/MoOx exhibits the highest Ni0 and Sn0 content, indicating that it has the strongest synergistic interaction between Ni and Sn, which promotes the reduction of the catalyst, resulting in the formation of more active centers for hydrogenation, which is consistent with the results of H2-TPR in Fig. 2(a). In Fig. 2(d), the high-resolution XPS spectra of Sn 3d5/2 can be deconvoluted into three peaks located at 487.1 eV, 486.3 eV, and 484.9 eV, which are attributed to Sn4+, Sn2+, and Sn0 species, respectively. This mixed oxidation state profile confirms the presence of SnO species, which function as Lewis acid sites for CO group adsorption and activation [51,56]. It can be observed that the ratio of Sn0/(Sn0 + Sn2++Sn4+) first increases and then decreases with increasing Sn loading, indicating that excessive Sn content suppresses the reducibility of catalyst, which is consistent with the H2-TPR results in Fig. 2(a). Among the catalysts, Ni4Sn1/MoOx exhibits the strongest Sn0 3d5/2 peak intensity and the highest Sn0/(Sn0 + Sn2++Sn4+) ratio (Table 2). This demonstrates that optimal Sn loading enhances reducibility, thereby facilitating Ni-Sn alloy formation. Furthermore, in Table 2, Ni4Sn1/MoOx also presents the highest Sn2+/(Sn0 + Sn2++Sn4+) ratio and exhibits the highest selectivity to 2-MF (Fig. 1(d)), further confirming that SnO can act as Lewis acid sites, thus facilitating the adsorption and activation of CO/CO [51,56]. Fig. 2(e, f) and S5(a-d) shows the in-situ CO-adsorbed infrared spectra (In-situ CO-IR) of the catalysts. The peaks at 2178 cm−1 and 2120 cm−1 are ascribed to gaseous CO, emerge immediately upon CO purging and gradually intensify across all the catalysts [57]. Upon Ar introduction, the gaseous CO peaks diminish progressively, leaving only persistent adsorption bands at ∼ 1950 cm−1 and ∼ 2050 cm−1 (Fig. 2(g)). Previous studies indicate that CO adsorption on Sn sites remains undetectable at room temperature [35,48]. In contrast, CO adsorption on Ni/MoOx exhibits two distinct modes: linear adsorption at a single Ni site (2054 cm−1) and multicoordinated adsorption across contiguous Ni sites (1950 cm−1) [45,48,58]. The NinSn1/MoOx catalysts (n = 2, 3, 4, 5) exhibit a single CO adsorption peak at ∼ 2046 cm−1, corresponding to linearly adsorbed CO on isolated Ni sites. This observation confirms the high dispersion of Ni species in the bimetallic catalysts [48]. Interestingly, the intensity of the CO linear adsorption peak decreases progressively with increasing Sn content. Notably, a broad peak emerges at 1947 cm−1 for Ni1Sn1/MoOx, corresponding to multicoordinated CO adsorption on Ni sites. This observation indicates that excessive Sn loading induces Ni nanoparticle agglomeration, which directly correlates with the diminished catalytic performance of Ni1Sn1/MoOx [58]. It is also found that the CO linear adsorption peak exhibits a red shift from 2054 cm−1 (Ni/MoOx) to 2046 cm−1 (NinSn1/MoOx (n = 1, 2, 3, 5)) and 2043 cm−1 (Ni4Sn1/MoOx), attributable to the electron transfer from Sn to Ni. The increased electron density of Ni enhances the electron feedback from the d orbital of the metal Ni to the antibonding orbitals of CO (π*), thereby weakening the CO bond. The most pronounced effect occurs in Ni4Sn1/MoOx, where maximal electron density enhancement optimizes this mechanism [45,48,57,59]. In addition, the absorption bands (2000–2100 cm−1) corresponding to CO adsorption exhibit significant intensity variations across different catalysts. Compared to monometallic Ni/MoOx, the NinSn1/MoOx (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) demonstrates enhanced band intensities, indicative of superior Ni dispersion. Notably, Ni4Sn1/MoOx exhibits the strongest absorption bands, indicating the strongest linear adsorption of CO and the highest Ni dispersion, this trend correlates well with the metal nanoparticle size distribution (TEM in Table S1) [60]. Fig. 3 (a) shows the possible reaction pathway of FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF. Fig. 3(b) exhibits the NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts·NH3-TPD analysis reveals that both Ni/MoOx and NinSn1/MoOx catalysts possess two types of acid sites: weak acid sites (50 ℃～265 ℃) and strong acid sites (400 ℃～500 ℃). Notably, the bimetallic catalysts exhibit a higher weak acid site concentration (≥106.6 μmol/g) compared to monometallic Ni/MoOx. This enhancement, attributed to SnO phase formation, demonstrates that Sn incorporation effectively increases catalytically active weak acid sites. As shown in Table S2, the Ni4Sn1/MoOx catalyst exhibits the highest weak acid concentration (326.8 μmol/g) and total acid density (373.3 μmol/g), demonstrating that optimal Sn doping maximizes acid site formation. Fig. 3(c) shows the in-situ Py-IR spectra of the catalysts. The primary absorption bands at 1439 cm−1 and 1575 cm−1 correspond to pyridine adsorption on Lewis acid sites (LAS). This observation confirms that all catalysts predominantly feature Lewis acidity, which facilitates the activation of CO and COH bonds through electron-deficient metal centers [61–63]. The bimetallic catalysts demonstrate significantly stronger Lewis acid site (LAS) signals compared to their monometallic catalysts. This enhanced Lewis acidity, evidenced by increased pyridine adsorption band intensities, correlates with the formation of SnO species following Sn incorporation. Significantly, Table S2 reveals that Ni4Sn1/MoOx exhibits the highest Lewis acid site (LAS) concentration (356.9 μmol/g) and the lowest Brønsted-to-Lewis acid ratio (B/L = 0.044). This phenomenon can be attributed to optimal Sn doping, which promotes SnO species formation and thereby maximizes LAS density. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the catalysts in furfural hydrodeoxygenation The catalytic performances of NinSn1/MoOx and monometallic Ni/MoOx in the HDO of FFR are summarized in Fig. 1(d) and Table S3. Table S3 (Entry 1) shows that the FFR does not convert without catalysts. As shown in Table S3, the NinSn1/MoOx catalysts exhibit higher FFR conversion than the monometallic Ni/MoOx. This enhancement is attributed to the improved dispersion of metal nanoparticles and the formation of Ni-Sn alloys. However, FFR conversion decreases with increasing Sn loading beyond the optimal ratio, primarily due to the inhibited catalyst reducibility by excess Sn species and the blockage of active sites via SnOx over-coverage. As shown in Fig. 1(d) and Table S3, Ni/MoOx achieves only 48.9 % selectivity toward 2-methylfuran (2-MF), with significant formation of intermediates and by-products. This limited selectivity stems from its low Lewis acid site (LAS) density (106.6 μmol/g, Table S2), which hinders efficient COH bond activation required for selective hydrodeoxygenation. Remarkably, Sn incorporation into NinSn1/MoOx catalysts significantly enhances 2-methylfuran (2-MF) yields while effectively suppressing the formation of the cyclization by-product tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) to negligible levels. These results arise from the synergistic Ni-Sn interaction, which promotes the formation of Ni-Sn alloys and SnO species. This dual structural effect suppresses undesired furan ring hydrogenation and enhances COH bond adsorption and cleavage efficiency. Notably, Ni4Sn1/MoOx achieves exceptional 2-methylfuran (2-MF) selectivity (99.8 %), which is directly attributed to its maximal LAS density (356.9 μmol/g, Table S2). However, exceeding the optimal Sn loading reduces LAS concentration, resulting in a 46 % decline in 2-MF yield. Besides, the H2-TPD and NH3-TPD of Ni/SnO are shown in Fig. S6. The results show that Ni4Sn1/MoOx exhibits stronger H2 adsorption/activation capability and greater weak-acid-site density (Detailed descriptions are shown in the Supporting Information). Moreover, Table S3 (Entry 8) shows the catalytic performance of Ni/SnO in the hydrodeoxygenation of furfural. As observed, NinSn1/MoOx exhibits higher conversion than Ni/SnO, presumably because its highly dispersed Ni-Sn alloy nanoparticles facilitate H2 adsorption and activation. This aligns with the H2-TPD results in Figs. 2(b) and Fig. S6(a). Furthermore, Ni/SnO exhibits only a 22.6 % 2-MF yield with 38.3 % selectivity for THFA, attributed to its relatively low acid density (Fig. S6(b)). Additionally, the catalytic performance and the TOF values of different metal catalysts for FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF are summarized in Table S4. Notably, Ni4Sn1/MoOx exhibits a high TOF value and achieves exceptional catalytic performance with a 99.8 % 2-MF yield under mild conditions (170 °C, 2 MPa H2). This surpasses conventional 5Cu3Re/Al2O3 (94.0 % yield) and rivals noble metal catalysts in activity. Furthermore, owing to its low cost and mild reaction conditions, Ni4Sn1/MoOx offers a promising alternative to noble metal catalysts for furfural (FFR) hydrodeoxygenation. Fig. 3(d) compares the catalytic performance of Ni4Sn1/MoOx reduced at different temperatures. The catalyst reduced at 450 °C achieves optimal performance with 99.8 % 2-MF yield. At lower reduction temperatures (400 °C), simultaneous formation of 2-MF and furfuryl alcohol (FA) occurs, indicating incomplete catalyst reduction. Fig. S7(a, b) shows TEM images of Ni4Sn1/MoOx after reduction at different temperatures. The metal nanoparticles undergo significant sintering, with the average particle size increasing from 5.7 nm to 11.4 nm as the reduction temperature rises from 450 ℃ to 550 ℃. This indicates that excessively high reduction temperatures are detrimental to metal nanoparticle dispersion. Moreover, when the reduction temperature increases to 500 and 550 ℃, the 2-MF yield decreases significantly, with by-products FA and THFA appearing. This is attributed to metal nanoparticle sintering at high reduction temperatures, as evidenced by the TEM results in Fig. S7. Subsequently, the effects of reaction conditions on FFR hydrodeoxygenation over Ni4Sn1/MoOx were carried out (Fig. 3(e-g)). Fig. 3(e) shows the distribution of the products at different reaction temperatures. At 140 °C, the main product on Ni4Sn1/MoOx is FA with a selectivity of 67.5 %. When the reaction temperature reaches 160 ℃, FFR is completely converted and the selectivity of 2-MF rises to 60.1 %. As the temperature increases to 170 °C, the yield of 2-MF reaches 99.8 %, demonstrating that the cleavage of the COH group in FA is influenced by reaction temperature. Fig. 3(f) illustrates the impact of reaction time on product distribution. When the reaction is conducted for 2 h, the conversion of FFR is only 58.5 % and FA is the main product with 77.7 % selectivity. As the reaction time increases, the yield of 2-MF gradually increases. When the reaction time is extended to 8 h, FFR is completely converted and the yield of 2-MF reaches 99.8 %. Therefore, it can be inferred that the CO group of FFR is preferentially hydrogenated to produce FA, and then the CO bond of FA is broken to produce 2-MF. What’s more, as seen in Fig. 3(g), the yield of 2-MF gradually increases as the H2 pressure increases from 1 MPa to 2 MPa. Then the yield of 2-MF is almost unchanged with the increment of reaction pressure. Furthermore, the scale-up process is also investigated. As shown in Table S3 (Entries 9–11), Ni4Sn1/MoOx exhibits excellent catalytic performance with increasing furfural concentration. Moreover, when FA is used as the initial reaction raw material, the results in Table S3 (Entry 12) show that the FA is completely converted over Ni4Sn1/MoOx at 8 h, and the yield of 2-MF reaches 98.6 %. Based on the above experimental results, it can be speculated that the path of FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF is: FFR → FA → 2-MF, in which the breakage of the COH group of FA is the rate-determining step, which is supported by the kinetic studies of the reaction (Fig. 4 ). Furthermore, to exclude the influence of catalytic transfer hydrogenation, the reaction under the N2 atmosphere is carried out. It can be seen that HDO activity over Ni4Sn1/MoOx decreases significantly, and 2-MF is undetectable under the same reaction conditions (Table S3 (Entry 13)). 3.3 Kinetic studies To further understand the reaction process of FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF over Ni4Sn1/MoOx, kinetic experiments were carried out. It is necessary to eliminate the effects of external diffusion before researching the kinetics of this reaction. As shown in Fig. S8, the impact of stirring speed on the conversion of different reactants was investigated. It can be seen that the conversion of FFR and the conversion of FA remains stable as the stirring speed increases above 500 rpm, indicating that the reaction enters the intrinsic region and the effect of external diffusion can be eliminated. Therefore, the stirring speed of 600 rpm was chosen for all subsequent experiments to avoid the kinetic limitations of external diffusion. It can be seen from Fig. 4(b, c) that ln(cA0/cA) is linearly related to the reaction time, which is in line with the first-order reaction kinetics model. Based on this, it can be assumed that the reaction of FFR hydrogenation and FA hydrodeoxygenation can be treated as the first-order reaction model, and a simplified reaction model of FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF is proposed (Fig. 4(a)) [64]. Table S5 summarizes the calculated results of the reaction rate constant k1 and k2 for FFR hydrogenation and FA hydrodeoxygenation. Notably, the reaction rate constant k2 for the conversion of FA to 2-MF is significantly lower than k1 at different temperatures, indicating that the hydrogenolysis of FA is the rate-determining step. Besides, the apparent activation energies (Ea ) calculated according to the Arrhenius equation are displayed in Fig. 4(d). It can be observed that the activation energy of FA hydrodeoxygenation (Ea = 69.7 kJ/mol) over Ni4Sn1/MoOx is higher than that of FFR hydrogenation (Ea = 60.6 kJ/mol), confirming that the hydrogenolysis of FA is the rate-determining step. Additionally, Table S6 summarizes the activation energies for each step of FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF in different literature. The Ea value for FFR hydrogenation to FA is significantly lower than those reported for non-noble metal catalysts and approaches values typical of noble-metal systems. Meanwhile, the Ea value for FA hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF is lower than those of other non-noble-metal catalysts, explaining the outstanding activity of the Ni4Sn1/MoOx catalyst. 3.4 Recycle stability of Ni4Sn1/MoOx The stability of catalysts is a crucial property in catalytic technology, and the stability of Ni4Sn1/MoOx was investigated. As shown in Fig. 5 (a) and Fig. S9(a), the results of cyclic experiments at different FFR conversions were acquired by regulating reaction conditions. It can be concluded that Ni4Sn1/MoOx exhibits excellent stability over six experimental cycles with insignificant loss of activity. Moreover, to demonstrate the critical role of the catalysts, thermal separation experiments were performed. It can be seen from Fig. 5(b) that there is no appreciable change in the conversion of FFR and the yield of 2-MF after the hot filtration of the catalyst. Meanwhile, the used catalyst was characterized using XRD, NH3-TPD, in-situ Py-IR, and XPS. As shown in Fig. 5(c–g), the crystal phase, surface chemical state, and acidity distribution of the used catalyst remain similar to those of the fresh catalyst. Furthermore, the EDS elemental mapping of the used catalyst (Fig. 5(h)) shows that the spatial distribution of different elements is uniform and free of agglomeration and sintering. The above results confirm that Ni4Sn1/MoOx has excellent catalytic stability. Moreover, Fig. S9(b) indicates that the additional 3.3 % weight loss on the TG curve of the used Ni4Sn1/MoOx catalyst likely originates from decomposition of surface-accumulated organic materials. Additionally, Fig. S9(c) reveals no significant nanoparticle sintering in the used catalyst, with an average particle size of 6.3 nm. Thus, the slight decrease in FFR conversion during the sixth cycle appears linked to carbon deposition. 3.5 Reaction mechanism In-situ DRIFTS was carried out to investigate the interactions between the catalyst and FFR and intermediates (Fig. 6 (a–c)). For gaseous adsorbed FFR, the peak at 1716 cm−1 is attributed to ν(CO) in the aldehyde group, whereas the peaks at 1575 cm−1 and 1478 cm−1 are ascribed to furan ring breath and ν(CC), respectively. As shown in Fig. 6(a), the characteristic peaks of the CO group on Ni/MoOx and NinSn1/MoOx (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) undergo a significant redshift in comparison with gaseous FFR, indicating that the CO bond is weakened and activated. Remarkably, it can be observed that the characteristic peak of the CO group shifts from 1716 cm−1 to the low-wave number 1671 cm−1 when FFR interacts with Ni4Sn1/MoOx, indicating the strongest chemisorption of CO on Ni4Sn1/MoOx, which is favorable for the conversion of FFR to the intermediate FA. This result may be due to the presence of SnO on the catalyst surface, which adsores more electron-rich O atoms from the asymmetric CO group than symmetric O atoms in the ring of furan. Additionally, the adsorption peaks of the furan ring and CC on Ni/MoOx and NinSn1/MoOx do not exhibit significant redshift, indicating the slight adsorption of the furan ring, which may be the reason for the lower generation of the cycloaddition product. The adsorption of the intermediate FA on Ni/MoOx and NinSn1/MoOx (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) are shown in Fig. 6(b), the adsorption peaks at 1014 cm−1 and 1149 cm−1 are attributed to ν(CO) and ν(COC) in the furan ring, respectively, which align with the spectra of the gaseous FA, suggesting that the adsorption of furan ring on the catalysts is weak [64–66]. Noticeably, compared with Ni/MoOx and gaseous FA, the adsorption peaks of CO on NinSn1/MoOx (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) present redshift from 1087 cm−1 to 1078 cm−1, indicating that the introduction of Sn can enhance the adsorption of CO group and facilitate the cleavage of the COH bond, hence favors the generation of 2-MF. In Fig. 6(c), the adsorption peaks at 1515 cm−1 and 1452 cm−1 are attributed to the furan ring breath and ν(CC), respectively [64]. It can be found that the adsorption of 2-MF on different catalysts is almost the same as the gaseous adsorption of 2-MF, indicating that 2-MF molecule does not undergo any additional transformation. Based on the above studies, the possible reaction mechanism is proposed and shown in Fig. 6(d). Firstly, the CO groups of FFR are adsorbed by the SnO sites, and then the active H* attacks the polarized CO to form the FA. Subsequently, the FA molecules adsorbed on the catalyst are attacked by the active H*, which achieves the breaking of the COH, resulting in the generation of 2-MF. 3.6 DFT calculations To have a more intuitive understanding of the mechanism of FFR hydrodeoxygenation over NinSn1/MoOx, the crystal surface models of Ni (111) and NixSn1 alloy (111) with different Ni/Sn ratios are established based on the density-functional theory (DFT) and the DMol3 module (Fig. S10). Fig. 7 (a2, b2) and Figs. S11(a2-d2) show the total electron density of Ni (111), Ni1Sn1 (111), Ni2Sn1 (111), Ni3Sn1 (111), Ni4Sn1 (111), and Ni5Sn1 (111) crystal surfaces, the blue regions represent the electron-deficient state, while the orange regions represent the electron-rich state. It is noteworthy that Ni atoms exhibit a higher charge density in NixSn1 (111) in comparison with Ni (111), indicating that the introduction of Sn significantly changes the electronic structure of Ni, which is consistent with the XPS results in Fig. 2. In addition, when the Ni/Sn is 4/1, Ni atoms exhibit the highest charge density in Ni4Sn1 (111), indicating that the suitable amount of Sn doping encourages the transfer of more electrons from Sn to Ni, and hence affects substrate adsorption. As shown in Fig. 7(c) and Figs. S12(a–f), the d-band center of Ni (111), Ni1Sn1 (111), Ni2Sn1 (111), Ni3Sn1 (111), Ni4Sn1 (111), and Ni5Sn1 (111) relative to the Fermi level (Ef ) are −1.81 eV, −1.92 eV, −2.01 eV, −2.14 eV, −2.18 eV, and −2.08 eV, indicating that the d-band center is far away from the Fermi level after Sn doping. Notably, the Ni4Sn1 (111) crystal surface shows the lowest d-band center, suggesting that the suitable amount of Sn doping induces an increase in the number of electrons in the antibonding state and a downward shift of the d-band center, leading to a decrease in the adsorption energy of H* on the metal sites, thus improving hydrogenation activity. Fig. S13 illustrates the different adsorption configurations of H2 molecules on Ni (111) and NixSn1(111) (x = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) crystal surfaces at Bridge, Face-centered cubic (Fcc), Hexagonal close-packed (Hcp), Parallel, and Top on Ni position, and the corresponding calculated results is illustrated in Fig. S14. As can be seen from Fig. S14, the largest H2 adsorption energies of Ni (111), Ni1Sn1 (111), Ni2Sn1 (111), Ni3Sn1 (111), Ni4Sn1 (111), and Ni5Sn1 (111) crystal surfaces are −0.62 eV, −0.71 eV, −0.79 eV, −0.91 eV, −1.18 eV, −1.09 eV, respectively, and the corresponding distances of H-H bond are stretched to 1.098 Å, 1.219 Å, 1.301 Å, 1.390 Å, 1.564 Å, and 1.486 Å. It can be seen that the adsorption energies of H2 on NixSn1 (111) are higher than that on Ni (111), indicating that the NixSn1 (111) crystal surfaces are more favorable for the adsorption and activation of H2, which is in agreement with the results of H2-TPD. Particularly, the Ni4Sn1 (111) crystal surface presents the largest H2 adsorption energy (Eads = −1.18 eV) and the H-H bond is stretched to 1.564 Å, suggesting that H2 is most readily activated on the Ni4Sn1 (111) crystal surface. Fig. S15 shows the adsorption models of active hydrogen (H*) at the Bridge, Face-centered cubic, Hexagonal close-packed, and Top on Ni positions of Ni (111), Ni1Sn1 (111), Ni2Sn1 (111), Ni3Sn1 (111), Ni4Sn1 (111), and Ni5Sn1 (111) crystal surfaces. As can be seen in Fig. S16, the lowest adsorption energies of H* on different crystal surfaces are −1.13 eV, −1.06 eV, −0.97 eV, −0.81 eV, −0.58 eV, and −0.69 eV, respectively. Among them, the lowest adsorption energies of H* on the crystal surfaces of NixSn1 (111) are lower than that of Ni (111), indicating that the H* is more easily to desorb from the NixSn1 (111) crystal surfaces. In addition, the lowest adsorption energies of H* on the crystal surfaces of NixSn1 (111) firstly decrease and then increase with the increment of Sn doping. It is worth noting that the crystal surface of Ni4Sn1 (111) exhibits the lowest adsorption energy of H* (−0.58 eV) at the Top on Ni position, suggesting that the H* is most easily desorbed from the Ni4Sn1 (111) crystal surface. The adsorption models of FFR molecule on Ni (111), Ni1Sn1 (111), Ni2Sn1 (111), Ni3Sn1 (111), Ni4Sn1 (111), and Ni5Sn1 (111) crystal surfaces in parallel and perpendicular states are shown in Fig. S17. Moreover, the calculated results of FFR adsorption are shown in Fig. S18. In Fig. S18, the largest adsorption energies of FFR on different crystal surfaces show the following order: Eads (Ni4Sn1 (111)) > Eads (Ni3Sn1 (111)) > Eads (Ni5Sn1 (111)) > Eads (Ni2Sn1 (111)) > Eads (Ni1Sn1 (111)) > Eads (Ni (111)). Obviously, the FFR adsorption energy of NixSn1 (111) crystal surfaces is notably higher than that of Ni (111), indicating that the presence of Sn promotes the adsorption and activation of FFR. Particularly, Ni4Sn1 (111) exhibits the largest adsorption energy of FFR (Eads = −4.26 eV) and the longest CO bond distance (1.825 Å), indicating that the CO bond is most readily activated on Ni4Sn1 (111), hence it is conducive to the generation of FA. Fig. S19 shows the adsorption models of FA molecules on Ni (111), Ni1Sn1 (111), Ni2Sn1 (111), Ni3Sn1 (111), Ni4Sn1 (111), and Ni5Sn1 (111) crystal surfaces in parallel and perpendicular states, and the corresponding calculations are summarized in Fig. S20. It can be seen that the largest adsorption energies of FA on Ni (111), NixSn1 (111) crystal surfaces are −3.25 eV, −3.58 eV, −3.81 eV, −4.18 eV, −4.75 eV, and −4.05 eV, respectively. In particular, Ni4Sn1 (111) exhibits the largest adsorption energy (Eads = −4.75 eV) and the longest CO bond distance (1.893 Å), suggesting that the CO bond in FA is more likely to be activated on Ni4Sn1 (111) crystal surface, thus promoting CO bond breakage, hence improves the yield of 2-MF. The calculation results of 2-MF on Ni (111), Ni1Sn1 (111), Ni2Sn1 (111), Ni3Sn1 (111), Ni4Sn1 (111), and Ni5Sn1 (111) crystal surfaces in parallel and perpendicular states are presented in Fig. S21. It can be concluded from Fig. S21 that the lowest adsorption energies of 2-MF on different crystal surfaces show the following order: Eads (Ni4Sn1 (111)) ＜ Eads (Ni3Sn1 (111)) ＜ Eads (Ni5Sn1 (111)) ＜ Eads (Ni2Sn1 (111)) ＜ Eads (Ni1Sn1 (111)) ＜ Eads (Ni (111)). Obviously, Ni4Sn1 (111) exhibits the lowest adsorption energy of 2-MF, suggesting that 2-MF can be effectively desorbed from Ni4Sn1 (111) crystal surface, thus avoiding further hydrogenation. The optimized structures and bond distances (in Å) for the intermediates and transition states of FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF on Ni (111), Ni1Sn1 (111), Ni2Sn1 (111), Ni3Sn1 (111), Ni4Sn1 (111), and Ni5Sn1 (111) crystal surfaces are listed in Figs. S22-S27, respectively. It can be seen that FFR (1) adsorbed on different crystal surfaces firstly converts to FA (2) by CO hydrogenation, after which the CO bond of FA is broken and finally dehydrates to form 2-MF (3), this is in agreement with the reaction pathway presented in Fig. 3(a). Moreover, Fig. 7(d) shows the calculated energy profiles for the potential comparative free energy of FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF on different crystal surfaces. As can be seen in Fig. 7(d), the CO bond in FFR (1) adsorbed on the different crystal surface is activated to combine with two H* (1a) and undergoes TS (1a-2) to form the intermediate product FA (2). In TS (1a-2), the energy barriers for CO activation on Ni (111), Ni1Sn1 (111), Ni2Sn1 (111), Ni3Sn1 (111), Ni4Sn1 (111), and Ni5Sn1 (111) crystal surfaces are 54.4 Kcal·mol−1, 49.6 Kcal·mol−1, 42.7 Kcal·mol−1, 38.9 Kcal·mol−1, 36.6 Kcal·mol−1, and 40.5 Kcal·mol−1, respectively. Notably, Ni4Sn1 (111) exhibits the lowest energy barrier of TS (1a-2), indicating that CO is easier to be activated on Ni4Sn1 (111) crystal surface. Subsequently, the C1-O1 bond of the intermediate FA (2) is again attacked by H* (2a) to form the final product 2-MF (3) via TS (2a-3). Apparently, as shown in Fig. 7(d), the energy barriers of TS (2a-3) for the hydrogenolysis of COH is significantly higher than those of TS (1a-2), suggesting that the hydrogenolysis of FA to 2-MF is the rate-determining step for the hydrodeoxygenation of FFR to 2-MF, which is in agreement with the results of the reaction kinetic studies (Fig. 4). Moreover, the energy barriers of TS (2a-3) on Ni (111), Ni1Sn1 (111), Ni2Sn1 (111), Ni3Sn1 (111), Ni4Sn1 (111), and Ni5Sn1 (111) crystal surfaces are 120.9 Kcal·mol−1, 115.0 Kcal·mol−1, 106.4 Kcal·mol−1, 97.6 Kcal·mol−1, 88.0 Kcal·mol−1, and 101.5 Kcal·mol−1. In particular, Ni4Sn1 (111) presents the lowest TS (2a-3) energy barrier, indicating that the cleavage of COH is most readily achieved on its surface. Overall, in-situ DRIFTS and DFT calculations demonstrate that FA is the key intermediate to obtain 2-MF, which confirms the findings of kinetic experiments. Importantly, Ni4Sn1 (111) crystal surface with the lowest d-band center and the strongest electronic effect shows the highest adsorption energies of H2, FFR, and FA, the lowest adsorption energies of H*, and 2-MF, and the lowest energy barrier of FA to 2-MF, which are key factors in obtaining high yield to 2-MF. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a series of NinSn1/MoOx (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) catalysts with varying metal ratios were synthesized via a glycine-assisted auto-ignition method and evaluated for FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF. It was found that that an optimal Sn loading enhances the Ni-Sn interaction, promoting the formation of Ni-Sn alloys and improving the dispersion of metal nanoparticles. More importantly, the appropriate Sn addition facilitates the generation of SnO species, which serve as Lewis acid sites and accelerate the hydrodeoxygenation of the intermediate furfuryl alcohol (FA) to 2-MF. In-situ DRIFTS analysis demonstrates that Sn incorporation strengthens the adsorption of the CO group in FFR and the COH group in FA, thereby enhancing 2-MF formation. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations further indicate that the Ni4Sn1 (111) crystal surface exhibits the lowest d-band center and the strongest electronic effect. Consequently, this surface shows the highest adsorption energies for H2, FFR, and FA, the lowest adsorption energies for H* and 2-MF, and the smallest energy barrier for the conversion of FA to 2-MF. As a result, the Ni4Sn1/MoOx catalyst achieves exceptional performance, delivering a 99.8 % yield of 2-MF at 170 °C. This work provides a novel strategy for designing efficient non-noble metal catalysts for the selective conversion of biomass-derived furfural to 2-MF. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrodeoxygenation of furfural (FFR) to 2-methylfuran (2-MF) is crucial for the high-value utilization of biomass resources. In this study, a series of NinSn1/MoOx (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) catalysts with varying metal ratios were synthesized via a glycine-assisted auto-ignition method and evaluated for FFR hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MF. The results reveal that an optimal Sn loading enhances the Ni-Sn interaction, promoting the formation of Ni-Sn alloys and improving the dispersion of metal nanoparticles. More importantly, the appropriate Sn addition facilitates the generation of SnO species, which serve as Lewis acid sites and accelerate the hydrodeoxygenation of the intermediate furfuryl alcohol (FA) to 2-MF. In-situ DRIFTS analysis demonstrates that Sn incorporation strengthens the adsorption of the CO group in FFR and the COH group in FA, thereby enhancing 2-MF formation. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations further indicate that the Ni4Sn1 (111) crystal surface exhibits the lowest d-band center and the strongest electronic effect. Consequently, this surface shows the highest adsorption energies for H2, FFR, and FA, the lowest adsorption energies for H* and 2-MF, and the smallest energy barrier for the conversion of FA to 2-MF. As a result, the Ni4Sn1/MoOx catalyst achieves exceptional performance, delivering a 99.8 % yield of 2-MF at 170 °C. This work provides a novel strategy for designing efficient non-noble metal catalysts for the selective conversion of biomass-derived furfural to 2-MF.
